sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: Ocha keeps a searchable database of your user files, bookmarks and applications and offers quick searching and launching for these files.
This application is inspired from Quicksilver for OSX, but for the GNOME desktop.

listitem.para: Applications
User files
Firefox and Mozilla bookmarks

sect2.title: To Start &app;
sect2.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para:
Choose
Utilities Ocha .
To start &app; from a command line, type the following command, then press Return:
Press &shortcut;, type ocha and then press Return (Provided ocha daemon is already running)

sect2.title: When You Start &app; for the first time
sect2.para: When you start &app; for the first time, it'll need to go through your files and index them. This shouldn't take long, unless you have many files in your home directory or My Documents.

&app; will open a wizard telling you what it is doing. At the end of the process, &app; will have been launched and ran on your system. You'll be able to invoke &app; at any time by pressing &shortcut; (This keyboard accelerator can be modified on the preference screen)
Later, when you start the application again, the preference screen will open.

sect2.title: Search and Launch
sect2.para: To look for a file, application or bookmarked link, press &shortcut; (or whatever keyboard accelerater you assigned to &app;). This will open the query window.

Then type a portion of the filename/title you're looking for. After each keypress, &app; ocha will present you with a list of possible files, application or link. Once you've found what you were looking for, select it using the up and down arrow and press Return to launch it.
To cancel a search, press Esc.
Press Space to separate portions of the filename/title you're looking for. For example, if you type holiday greece, it'll match My holidays in Greece in 2005 as well as Greece Holiday.mpg.

sect1.title: Settings
sect1.para:
To configure &app;, either choose
Utilities Ocha on the GNOME menu or, if ocha daemon is running, press &shortcut;, type ocha and then press Return.
This will open the Preferences dialog, which contains the following tabbed sections:

listitem.para: This is the keyboard shortcut that will open the query window.
To change the accelerator, click on the button and press the key you'd like to use to start a query.

Choose here how often you'd like &app; to refresh its cache. It'll take that long for a new file or bookmark to be taken into account when running a query &app;, so you might want to set a small value here. On the other hand, updating the catalog will access your hard disk and might slow down your computer while it is in action.
Choose one of the following:
Select this option if you don't want ocha to ever run an automatic update of the index.
If you choose this option, the index will never be updated unless you refresh a source manually from the catalog tab

You might want to select this option so that you can choose the exact time at which the catalog is updated. Run the command ocha index from a cron job or from the command line when you want ocha to update the catalog.
Choose this option if you want &app; to update the catalog every 10 minutes.
That might be too often, especially if you've got a slow hard disk.
Choose this option if you want &app; to update the catalog every 30 minutes.
Choose this option if you want &app; to update the catalog every hour.
Choose this option if you want &app; to update the catalog once a day.

sect2.title: Catalog
sect2.para: On this tab, you'll find a list of indexed applications, directories or bookmarks.
On this list, you'll always find:

listitem.para: Your GNOME/KDE desktop.
The applications installed on your system.

sect2.para: You might also see the Mozilla or Firefox profiles ocha detected on your system. Each profile corresponds to a bookmark file.
Here's what you can do on this tab:

sect3.title: Add new directories to be indexed
sect3.para: To add new directories, you can click on New, then choose the directory.
Faster: drop directories from nautilus into the catalog list.
After adding a new directory, select the directory and click Refresh for its content to be indexer.

sect3.title: Refresh individual sources
sect3.para: If you have added a new file, application or bookmark entry and would like it to be immediately available for searching, select the source that has been modified and click on Refresh.

sect3.title: Delete directory sources
sect3.para: To remove an indexed directory, select the directory and click on Delete.

Sources added automatically by &app; cannot be deleted. You might achieve the same result by unchecking the sources you don't want. Sources without a checkmark on the right won't be taken into account while searching

sect3.title: Ignore irrelevant sources
sect3.para: Remove the checkmark on the right of the entry for its content to be ignored while searching.

sect3.title: Ignore annoying entries
sect3.para: If a source contains an entry you know you'll never want, you might disable that entry.
To do so, double-click on the source, then go to the tab Contents, look for the entry and uncheck it.
Alternatively, for directories you added manually, you migth double-click on the entry, then type in patterns of files that must be ignored in this directory in the Excludetextbox.

sect2.title: Stop
sect2.para: This tab contains one button, Stop Ocha Daemon. Click on it if you don't want &app; to run on your system anymore.
You might decide to reinstall &app; ocha by running the command ochad from the terminal.

listitem.para: Indexing of remote (SMB/NFS) directories might overtax your network.
It's much too ugly and needs nice icans.
